titleStmt.title: Some small faults (on purpose) escaped in the printing, lest the Reader should think that the Booke were guilty of being too much sense∣able or sententious.

publicationStmt.publisher: To the Reader: The English Preface in Print, c. 1475-1640 / Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership

analytic.title: Some small faults (on purpose) escaped in the printing, lest the Reader should think that the Booke were guilty of being too much sense∣able or sententious.

monogr.title: The legend of Sir Leonard Lack-wit : sonne in law to Sir Gregory Nonesence, by the marriage of his wiues eldest daughter to Sir Simon Simple, translated out of all Christian languages into the Kentish tongue. By Martin Parker
monogr.author: M. P. (Martin Parker)

div.head: Some small faults (on purpose) escaped in the printing, lest the Reader should think that the Booke were guilty of being too much senseable or sententious.
div.p: IN the 1099. page, line 205. for time read hard. In the 300. page, line 400 for merchant read a meere cheater: in the 65. page line 290. for powderd beefe read mustard: in the 103. page, line 88. for wives read few good: in the 709. page, line 11000. for morice dancers read a Tabber and pipe: in the 608. page line 96. for a pot of Ale read a penny: in the 150. page, line 900. for Poetry read poverty: in the 570. page, line 87. for an Owle read an Ivie tree, in the 48. page, line 80. for Marshalmen, red mercilesse men: in the 600. page, line 99. for a Tinker read a budget: in the 67. page, line 52. for a Cuckold read hornes.
These with a great many other faults the intellectual Reader may easily mend when he meets them in his dish.
